home.featured.title: Featured: Electricity & Magnetism
home.electricity.title: What is electric current?
home.electricity.description: Discover the true nature of electric current. Find out why electrons move slowly but the signal is instantaneous and how AC current works in your home.
home.otherTopics.title: Other topics to explore
dailyFact.title: Fact of the Day
dailyFacts.electronFact.title: Electron fact
dailyFacts.electronFact.content: The drift velocity of electrons in a conductor is only a few millimeters per hour, but the electrical signal travels at the speed of light!
quiz.title: Adaptive Quiz
quiz.description: The quiz is a knowledge test that adapts to your level. Questions are generated dynamically, and their difficulty level depends on your answers.
quiz.question: Question {current} of {total}
quiz.resultText: Thank you for completing the quiz! Your score is {score} out of {total} possible points.
quiz.achievementText: Completed the first chapter on electric current!
quiz.q1.question: What is the typical drift velocity of electrons in a household conductor?
quiz.q1.explanation: Electrons drift very slowly, but the electrical signal travels at the speed of light.
circuitBuilder.title: Circuit Builder
circuit.remember: Remember, to build a closed circuit, you need a power source (battery), a receiver (bulb), and wires. Try adding a switch to control the current flow!
circuit.dropZoneAriaLabel: Circuit building area - drop components here
acCurrent.title: Alternating Current Visualization
acCurrent.description: Change the frequency of the alternating current and observe how electrons oscillate. Notice that energy is transmitted by the wave, not by the movement of electrons!
facts.subtitle: The most interesting facts from the world of physics, biology, and astronomy
facts.fact1.title: The speed of light in vacuum
facts.fact1.content: Light in a vacuum travels at a speed of 299,792,458 meters per second. This is a precisely defined value that serves as the basis for defining the meter in the SI system. Nothing can move faster than light in a vacuum - this is a fundamental limitation from Einstein's theory of relativity.
facts.fact2.title: The color of the Sun
facts.fact2.content: The Sun emits light across a broad spectrum, which makes its true color white. The yellow or orange color we often see is due to Earth's atmosphere, which scatters shorter wavelength light (blue and violet), especially during sunrise and sunset.
facts.fact3.title: Genetic code
facts.fact3.content: The genetic code is a set of rules used by living cells to translate information encoded in genetic material (DNA or RNA) into proteins. It consists of codons - sequences of three nucleotides that specify which amino acid should be added to the protein chain. This code is almost universal among all known life forms.
facts.fact4.title: The Grand Canyon's growth
facts.fact4.content: The Grand Canyon is still being carved by the Colorado River, although the process is very slow. The river erodes the rock by about 0.1 mm per year. This erosion, combined with the tectonic uplift of the Colorado Plateau, continues to deepen and widen the canyon over millions of years.
facts.fact5.title: Neutrino mass
facts.fact5.content: For a long time, neutrinos were thought to be massless. However, the discovery of neutrino oscillations proved that they have a tiny but non-zero mass. This discovery was a significant breakthrough in particle physics and is still a subject of intense research.
facts.fact6.title: Bioluminescence
facts.fact6.content: Bioluminescence is the production and emission of light by a living organism as a result of a chemical reaction. This phenomenon is observed in many creatures, from fireflies to deep-sea fish. The most common uses of bioluminescence are to attract mates or prey.
scaleExplorer.title: Playing with the scale of the universe
scaleExplorer.description: Travel through the scales of the universe - from the smallest particles to the largest galaxies. Interactive zoom helps you understand the relative size of objects.
scale.level.quark.name: Quark
scale.level.quark.description: Fundamental constituents of protons and neutrons

scale.hero.title: Scales of the Universe
scale.hero.subtitle: Travel from atoms to galaxies and discover the vastness of the Universe
scale.context.title: Understanding Scale in Physics
scale.context.why.title: Why does scale matter?
scale.context.why.text: Understanding the relative sizes of objects in the universe helps us grasp the complexity of physics at different levels—from quantum mechanics to cosmology.
scale.context.facts.title: Scale Facts:
scale.context.facts.atom: • If an atom were the size of a soccer ball, the nucleus would be the size of a grain of rice
scale.context.facts.human: • Humans are in the middle of the cosmic scale
scale.context.facts.galaxy: • A galaxy contains about 100 billion stars

mechanics.header.title: Mechanics
mechanics.header.subtitle: Explore the laws of motion and forces in nature
mechanics.newtonLaws.title: Newton's Laws
mechanics.newtonLaw1.title: Newton's First Law
mechanics.newtonLaw1.description: Law of Inertia - a body remains at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by a net force.
mechanics.newtonLaw2.title: Newton's Second Law
mechanics.newtonLaw2.description: The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting upon it and inversely proportional to its mass: F = ma
mechanics.newtonLaw3.title: Newton's Third Law
mechanics.newtonLaw3.description: Action-Reaction - For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
mechanics.pendulum.title: Mathematical Pendulum
mechanics.pendulum.description: Observe the motion of a pendulum and learn about the relationship between its oscillation period and length.
mechanics.pendulum.formulaDescription: where L is the length of the pendulum, g is the acceleration due to gravity
mechanics.mechanicalEnergy.title: Mechanical Energy
mechanics.kineticEnergy.title: Kinetic Energy
mechanics.kineticEnergy.description: Energy associated with the motion of an object. Depends on mass and velocity.
mechanics.potentialEnergy.title: Potential Energy
mechanics.potentialEnergy.description: Energy associated with the position of an object in a gravitational field.
mechanics.energyConservation.title: Law of Conservation of Mechanical Energy
mechanics.energyConservation.description: In an isolated system, the sum of kinetic and potential energy remains constant:
thermodynamics.header.subtitle: Discover the laws that govern heat and energy
thermodynamics.moleculeMotion.title: Molecule motion and temperature
thermodynamics.moleculeMotion.descriptio: Observe how temperature affects the speed of gas molecules.
thermodynamics.temperature.label: Temperature:
thermodynamics.speed.label: Speed: {speed}%
thermodynamics.laws.title: Laws of Thermodynamics
thermodynamics.laws.description: Learn the three fundamental laws of thermodynamics that describe the relationship between heat, work, and energy.
thermodynamics.firstLaw.title: First Law of Thermodynamics
thermodynamics.firstLaw.description: The internal energy of an isolated system is constant. Energy cannot be created or destroyed, it can only be converted from one form to another.
thermodynamics.firstLaw.formula: Change in Internal Energy = Heat Added - Work Done
thermodynamics.firstLaw.explanation: ΔU = change in internal energy, Q = heat, W = work
thermodynamics.secondLaw.title: Second Law of Thermodynamics
thermodynamics.secondLaw.description: The entropy of an isolated system never decreases. Heat spontaneously flows from hotter to colder bodies.
thermodynamics.hot.label: HOT
thermodynamics.cold.label: COLD
thermodynamics.thirdLaw.title: Third Law of Thermodynamics
thermodynamics.thirdLaw.description: The entropy of a perfect crystal at absolute zero is zero.
thermodynamics.thirdLaw.formula: At absolute zero temperature, entropy approaches zero
thermodynamics.processes.title: Thermodynamic Processes
thermodynamics.isothermalProcess.title: Isothermal Process
thermodynamics.isothermalProcess.descrip: Temperature remains constant throughout the process.
thermodynamics.adiabaticProcess.title: Adiabatic Process
thermodynamics.adiabaticProcess.descript: There is no heat exchange with the surroundings.
thermodynamics.isobaricProcess.title: Isobaric Process
thermodynamics.isobaricProcess.descripti: Pressure remains constant throughout the process.
thermodynamics.isochoricProcess.title: Isochoric Process
thermodynamics.isochoricProcess.descript: Volume remains constant throughout the process.
thermodynamics.temperature.title: Temperature and Particle Motion
thermodynamics.temperature.description: Move the slider to change the temperature and observe how the speed of the particles changes.
electromagnetism.header.subtitle: Explore the unity of electric and magnetic forces
electromagnetism.magneticFieldSimulation: Observe the magnetic field lines around a permanent magnet.
electromagnetism.magneticFieldProperties: • Field lines emerge from the N pole and enter the S pole
• Field lines never cross each other
• The density of the lines indicates the strength of the field
electromagnetism.maxwellEquations.title: Maxwell's Equations
electromagnetism.maxwellEquations.gaussE: The electric flux through a closed surface is proportional to the charge inside.
electromagnetism.maxwellEquations.gaussM: The magnetic flux through a closed surface is always zero.
electromagnetism.maxwellEquations.farada: A changing magnetic field induces an electric field.
electromagnetism.maxwellEquations.ampere: Current and a changing electric field produce a magnetic field.
electromagnetism.electromagneticWaves.sp: All electromagnetic waves travel at the speed of light in vacuum: c = 299,792,458 m/s
electromagnetism.waveType.xRays.title: X-rays
electromagnetism.frequencyWavelength.des: where c - speed of light, λ - wavelength, f - frequency
opticsDescription: Explore the fascinating world of optics, the branch of physics that studies the behavior and properties of light, including its interactions with matter and the construction of instruments that use or detect it.
opticsImageAlt: Diagram illustrating optical phenomena and light.
opticsMainHeading: The World of Light and Vision
lightNatureContent: Light, an electromagnetic wave, exhibits both wave-like and particle-like properties. It travels at an astonishing speed of approximately 299,792,458 meters per second in a vacuum, forming the basis of our visual perception.
reflectionRefractionContent: When light encounters a surface, it can be reflected or refracted. Reflection is the bouncing back of light from a surface, like a mirror. Refraction is the bending of light as it passes from one medium to another, such as light passing from air to water.
lensesMirrorsContent: Lenses use refraction to converge or diverge light, forming images, while mirrors use reflection. They are crucial in devices ranging from eyeglasses to telescopes.
opticalInstrumentsContent: Optical instruments leverage the principles of optics to enhance human vision or analyze light. This category includes devices like microscopes, telescopes, cameras, and fiber optics, each designed for specific applications in science, technology, and everyday life.
optics.refraction.title: Light Refraction
optics.refractiveIndex.label: Refractive index (n):
optics.snellsLaw.title: Snell's Law
optics.criticalAngle.title: Critical Angle
optics.criticalAngle.description: The angle of incidence for which the angle of refraction is 90°.
optics.wavelength.label: Wavelength:
optics.wavelength.description: Move the slider to change the wavelength of light and see how it affects its color. Remember that our eyes perceive only a narrow range of electromagnetic waves!
optics.lenses.title: Lenses
optics.lensDistance.label: Distance from the lens:
optics.lensFormula.title: Lens Formula
optics.lensFormula.example: f: {f} cm, d₀: {d} cm, dᵢ: {imgD, number, ::.1}, magnification: {mag, number, ::.1}
optics.gallery.title: Phenomena Gallery
optics.rainbow.title: Rainbow
optics.rainbow.content: The dispersion of white light by water droplets, creating a spectrum of colors.
optics.mirage.title: Mirage
optics.mirage.content: The refraction of light in layers of air with different temperatures creates apparent images.
optics.interference.title: Interference
optics.interference.content: The superposition of light waves leads to the reinforcement or cancellation of their amplitude, creating interference patterns.

modernPhysics.relativity.title: Theory of Relativity
modernPhysics.photoelectric.title: Photoelectric effect
modernPhysics.applications.title: Practical applications
modernPhysics.applications.nuclearReacti: Nuclear fission and fusion use mass defect to produce energy.
modernPhysics.applications.lasers.title: Lasers
modernPhysics.applications.lasers.descri: Quantum transitions of electrons in atoms produce coherent light.
modernPhysics.applications.gps.title: GPS
modernPhysics.applications.gps.subtitle: Relativistic correction
modernPhysics.applications.gps.descripti: The system requires accounting for time dilation effects from the theory of relativity.
modernphysics.hero.title: Modern Physics
modernphysics.hero.subtitle: Discover the mysteries of quanta, relativity and structure of matter
modernphysics.relativity.title: Theory of Relativity
modernphysics.relativity.effects.title: Relativistic Effects
modernphysics.quantum.title: Quantum Physics
modernphysics.particles.title: Elementary Particle Physics
modernphysics.particles.weakDescription: β decays, W and Z bosons
modernphysics.applications.title: Applications of Modern Physics
modernphysics.applications.nuclearDescri: Nuclear fission and fusion use mass defect to produce energy.
modernphysics.applications.lasersDescrip: Quantum transitions of electrons in atoms produce coherent light.
modernphysics.applications.gpsDescriptio: The system requires accounting for time dilation effects from relativity theory.
earthSpace.hero.title: Earth and Space
earthSpace.hero.subtitle: Discover the secrets of our planet and the universe
earthSpace.hero.imageAlt: An image of Earth from space, with visible city lights and the aurora borealis
earthSpace.seasons.title: Seasons - The True Cause
earthSpace.seasons.didYouKnowText: It's NOT the distance from the Sun that causes seasons! In January, the Earth is closest to the Sun, yet it's winter in the Northern Hemisphere.
earthSpace.seasons.currentTiltInfo: The current tilt of the Earth (23.5°) ensures distinct seasons.
earthSpace.gravity.title: Gravity - More Than You Think
earthSpace.gravity.forceDescription: Gravitational force between Earth and the Sun
earthSpace.einstein.title: Einstein's Theory of Relativity
earthSpace.einstein.newPerspectiveText: Einstein showed that gravity isn't a force, but a curvature of spacetime! Mass warps space, and objects move along the shortest paths.
earthSpace.einstein.classicalPhysicsText: Earth is attracted by the Sun
earthSpace.einstein.relativityTheoryText: Earth follows the curvature of spacetime
earthSpace.dayNight.title: Day and Night Cycle
earthSpace.dayNight.funFactText: Everyone on Earth is moving at an incredible speed! At the equator, it's 1670 km/h, and in Poland about 1200 km/h. Why don't we feel it? Because everything around us is moving at the same speed!
earthSpace.exploration.title: Space Exploration
planetaryMotion.title: Planetary motion around the Sun
planetaryMotion.description: Observe how planets move around the Sun at different speeds according to Kepler's laws.
billiardBalls.title: Billiard ball experiment
billiardBalls.analogy: Analogy of electron movement in a conductor - the balls represent atoms, the red ball is an electron
billiardBalls.howItWorksGrey: • Grey balls = atoms in a conductor
billiardBalls.howItWorksSignal: • Signal travels fast, electrons move slowly
billiards.title: Billiard balls experiment
billiards.description: Analogy of electron motion in a conductor - balls represent atoms, the red ball is the electron
billiards.legend.atoms: • Gray balls = atoms in the conductor
electricityMagnetism.header.title: Electricity and Magnetism
electricityMagnetism.header.description: Learn the secrets of current flow and electron behavior
electricityMagnetism.current.title: What is electric current?
electricityMagnetism.current.description: Electric current is the ordered movement of free electrons in a conductor. In metals, electrons can move freely between atoms, forming an 'electron sea'.
electricityMagnetism.electrons.title: Do electrons move in a wire?
electricityMagnetism.electrons.descripti: This is a common misconception! Electrons do move, but very slowly. Without voltage, they perform chaotic thermal motion, and with voltage, they slowly drift towards the positive pole.
electricityMagnetism.acCurrent.title: Alternating current in the socket
electricityMagnetism.acCurrent.descripti: In a household socket, we have alternating current - electrons do not flow in one direction, but oscillate back and forth 50 times per second (50 Hz in Europe).
electricityMagnetism.nextTopic.title: Next topic
electricityMagnetism.nextTopic.earthSpac: Discover the true cause of seasonal changes, learn about the action of gravity in relativity theory, and understand why the Sun rises and sets.
electricityMagnetism.nextTopic.earthMode: Model of Earth's movement around the Sun
electronDrift.title: Electron Drift Simulation
electronDrift.description: Observe the behavior of electrons in a conductor. Without voltage, they move chaotically; with voltage, they slowly drift in one direction.
error.devMessage: Something went wrong. Please try again later.
terms.title: Terms of Service
terms.introduction: Please read these Terms of Service carefully. By accessing or using our application, you agree to be bound by these terms.
terms.section1.title: 1. Definitions
terms.section1.content: The terms used in these regulations mean: Application - this educational platform; User - any natural person accessing the Application; Content - all materials, texts, graphics, interactive simulations provided in the Application.
terms.section2.title: 2. Acceptance of Terms
terms.section2.content: Using the Application is equivalent to full acceptance of these Terms. If you do not agree with any of the provisions, please stop using the Application.
terms.section3.title: 3. Use of the Application
terms.section3.content:
You agree to use the Application only for lawful purposes and for its intended purpose - that is, for educational purposes. It is forbidden to:

  • Disrupt the operation of the Application.
  • Attempt to gain unauthorized access to data.
  • Use the Application for commercial purposes without our written consent.
terms.section4.title: 4. Intellectual Property Rights
terms.section4.content: All Content available in the Application, including its source code, design, texts, and graphics, is our intellectual property or is licensed and protected by copyright law. We grant you a non-exclusive, non-transferable license to use the Content solely for personal, non-commercial use.
terms.section5.title: 5. User Accounts
terms.section5.content: If the Application requires creating an account, you are responsible for maintaining the confidentiality of your login details and for all activities that occur under your account. You must notify us immediately of any unauthorized use of your account.
terms.section6.title: 6. Limitation of Liability
terms.section6.content: The Application and its Content are provided 'as is'. We do not guarantee that the Application will operate uninterruptedly and without errors. To the fullest extent permitted by law, we are not liable for any damages resulting from the use or inability to use the Application.
terms.section7.title: 7. Changes to the Terms
terms.section7.content: We reserve the right to change these Terms at any time. We will inform you of any significant changes through the Application or by e-mail. Continued use of the Application after the changes are introduced means you accept them.
terms.section8.title: 8. Governing Law
terms.section8.content: These Terms are governed by Polish law. Any disputes arising from these Terms will be settled by the courts competent for our registered office.
terms.section9.title: 9. Termination
terms.section9.content: We may suspend or terminate your access to the Application at any time, without notice, if you breach these Terms.
terms.section10.title: 10. Contact
terms.section10.content: If you have any questions about these Terms, please contact us at: [Your Email Address].
privacy.title: Privacy Policy
privacy.introduction: This Privacy Policy describes how we collect, use, and protect your personal data when you use our Application. Your privacy is critically important to us.
privacy.section1.title: 1. Data Controller
privacy.section1.content: The controller of your personal data is [Your Name/Company] with its registered office in [City]. For matters related to data processing, you can contact us at: [Your Email Address].
privacy.section2.title: 2. What data do we collect?
privacy.section2.content:
We may collect the following types of information:

  • Data you provide voluntarily: such as email address, name, or nickname if you choose to create an account.
  • Usage data: information about your interaction with the Application, such as completed modules, quiz results, time spent. This data is anonymized where possible.
  • Technical data: such as IP address, browser type, operating system, collected automatically for security and analytical purposes.
privacy.section3.title: 3. Why do we process your data?
privacy.section3.content:
We process your data to:

  • Provide services within the Application.
  • Personalize the educational experience.
  • Analyze and improve the Application's performance.
  • Ensure security and prevent abuse.
  • Communicate with you on matters related to the Application (if you have an account).
privacy.section4.title: 4. Legal basis for processing
privacy.section4.content:
We process your data based on:

  • Your consent (Art. 6(1)(a) GDPR).
  • The necessity to perform a contract (Art. 6(1)(b) GDPR).
  • Our legitimate interest (Art. 6(1)(f) GDPR), such as analytics or security.
privacy.section5.title: 5. Who do we share data with?
privacy.section5.content: We do not sell your personal data. We may share it with trusted third parties only when necessary to provide our services (e.g., hosting service providers). All such partners are obliged to protect your data.
privacy.section6.title: 6. How long do we store data?
privacy.section6.content: We store your data for as long as it is necessary to achieve the purposes for which it was collected, or as long as you have an account in the Application. After this period, the data is deleted or anonymized.
privacy.section7.title: 7. Your rights
privacy.section7.content:
Under the GDPR, you have the following rights:

  • The right to access your data.
  • The right to rectify your data.
  • The right to erasure ('right to be forgotten').
  • The right to restrict processing.
  • The right to data portability.
  • The right to object.
  • The right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority.
privacy.section8.title: 8. Data security
privacy.section8.content: We use appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect your data from unauthorized access, loss, or destruction. This includes, among others, SSL connection encryption.
privacy.section9.title: 9. Changes to the Privacy Policy
privacy.section9.content: We reserve the right to make changes to this Policy. We will inform you of any changes within the Application. We encourage you to review this page regularly.
facts.hero.imageAlt: Visualization of scientific facts flying out of an open book
quiz.hero.imageAlt: Artistic visualization of a neural network in a human brain
boiling.title: Boiling Water
boiling.subtitle: Understanding phase transitions and molecular behavior
boiling.module.title: Water State Simulator
boiling.temperature.label: Temperature
boiling.explanation.title: The Physics of Boiling
boiling.point.title: Boiling Point
boiling.point.content: The temperature at which the vapor pressure of a liquid equals the external pressure. For water at sea level, it's 100°C (212°F).
boiling.pressure.title: Pressure and Boiling
boiling.pressure.content: The boiling point depends on pressure. In the mountains, where pressure is lower, water boils at a lower temperature.
taste.title: Perception of Taste
taste.subtitle: How our brain interprets chemical signals from the tongue
taste.module.title: Interactive Tongue Map
taste.module.description: Click on a taste to see where it is perceived. Find out that the popular taste map is a myth!
taste.myth.title: The Myth of the Taste Map
taste.myth.content: All tastes are perceived over the entire surface of the tongue! Different areas may have slightly higher sensitivity, but there are no rigidly defined zones.
taste.types.title: The Five Basic Tastes
taste.explanation.sweet: Detected by receptors that respond to sugars and some other substances, like sweeteners. It signals a source of energy.
taste.explanation.sour: Responds to acidity (H+ ions). It warns against unripe or spoiled foods.
taste.explanation.salty: Detected by ion channels for alkali metal ions, like sodium (Na+). Essential for maintaining fluid balance.
taste.explanation.bitter: Detected by a wide range of receptors. It often signals the presence of toxins, hence a natural aversion.
taste.explanation.umami: A 'meaty' or 'brothy' taste, triggered by glutamic acid. It signals the presence of protein.
microworld.title: Microworld
microworld.subtitle: Immerse yourself in the fascinating world of atoms, molecules, and cells
microworld.interactive.title: Interactive Microworld Explorations
microworld.interactive.description: Discover the structures and processes occurring at the smallest scale of reality
microworld.atom.title: Atomic Structure
microworld.atom.description: Explore the structure of the atom and the arrangement of electrons
microworld.atom.sodium.title: Sodium Atom (Na)
microworld.atom.sodium.fact1: • The nucleus contains 11 protons and 12 neutrons
microworld.atom.sodium.fact4: • Electrons orbit at a speed of ~2200 km/s
microworld.dna.title: DNA Structure
microworld.dna.description: Learn about the structure of deoxyribonucleic acid
microworld.dna.facts.title: Facts about DNA
microworld.dna.facts.fact3: • 4 nitrogenous bases: A, T, G, C
microworld.dna.facts.fact4: • DNA length in a cell: ~2 meters
microworld.cell.title: Cell Structure
microworld.cell.description: Explore the organelles of a eukaryotic cell
microworld.cell.organelleInfo.nucleus: The cell's control center containing DNA
microworld.summary.title: Levels of Microworld Organization
microworld.summary.atoms.title: Atoms
microworld.summary.atoms.fact2: • Composed of protons, neutrons, and electrons
microworld.summary.molecules.title: Molecules
microworld.summary.cells.title: Cells
microworld.summary.cells.fact4: • About 37 trillion in the human body
perception.header.title: Perception and Senses
perception.header.subtitle: Discover the fascinating world of human senses and perception
perception.modules.title: Interactive Modules
perception.modules.subtitle: Explore how our senses work through interactive experiments
perception.color.title: Color Perception
perception.color.description: Discover how the human eye perceives colors and how color blindness works
perception.color.fact1: • The human eye has 3 types of photoreceptors (cones)
perception.color.fact2: • Each type responds to different wavelengths of light
perception.color.fact3: • Color blindness is a deficiency in one of the cone types
perception.sound.title: Sound Perception
perception.sound.description: Explore how the ear perceives different sound frequencies
perception.sound.fact1: • Humans can hear frequencies from 20 Hz to 20 kHz
perception.sound.fact2: • The pitch of a sound depends on its frequency
perception.sound.fact3: • Loudness depends on the amplitude of the sound wave
perception.sound.fact4: • The middle ear amplifies sounds by 20-30 dB
perception.touch.title: Touch Perception
perception.touch.description: Learn about the differences in touch sensitivity across different body parts
perception.touch.fact1: • Fingertips are the most sensitive to touch
perception.touch.fact2: • Temperature and pain are sensed by separate receptors
perception.touch.fact3: • Mechanoreceptors respond to pressure and vibration
perception.touch.fact4: • The brain interprets signals from various receptors
perception.summary.title: Summary - How Our Senses Work
perception.summary.sight.title: Sight
perception.summary.sight.fact1: • The eye converts light into electrical signals
perception.summary.sight.fact2: • The retina contains rods and cones
perception.summary.sight.fact3: • The brain interprets images in the visual cortex
perception.summary.hearing.title: Hearing
perception.summary.hearing.fact1: • Sound waves cause the eardrum to vibrate
perception.summary.hearing.fact3: • The cochlea converts vibrations into nerve signals
perception.summary.touch.title: Touch
perception.summary.touch.fact2: • Different body parts have varying sensitivity
perception.summary.touch.fact3: • The brain maps the body's surface
perception.summary.tasteSmell.title: Taste & Smell
perception.summary.tasteSmell.fact2: • Smell is thousands of times more sensitive than taste
perception.summary.tasteSmell.fact3: • Both senses work together to identify foods
dailyFacts.gravityFact.title: Fact about Newton's Third Law
dailyFacts.gravityFact.content: According to Newton's Third Law, when you jump, you are actually pushing the entire planet Earth away from you. Of course, due to its gigantic mass, the Earth's movement is completely unnoticeable.
dailyFacts.microworldFact.title: Microworld Fact
dailyFacts.microworldFact.content: There are more atoms in a single drop of water than there are drops of water in all the oceans on Earth.
dailyFacts.opticsFact.title: Optics Fact
dailyFacts.opticsFact.content: The rainbow you see is unique to you. Someone standing even a meter away sees a different rainbow, formed by different water droplets.
dailyFacts.perceptionFact.title: Perception Fact
dailyFacts.perceptionFact.content: Your brain uses about 20% of the total oxygen and calories in your body, even though it only makes up about 2% of your body weight.
dailyFacts.thermodynamicsFact.title: Thermodynamics Fact
dailyFacts.thermodynamicsFact.content: Absolute zero temperature (-273.15°C) is not just very cold – it's the point at which all atomic motion ceases.
dailyFacts.earthSpaceFact.title: Space Fact
dailyFacts.earthSpaceFact.content: On Venus, a day is longer than a year. One rotation on its axis takes 243 Earth days, while its orbit around the Sun takes only 225.
dailyFacts.modernPhysicsFact.title: Quantum Physics Fact
dailyFacts.modernPhysicsFact.content: Billions of neutrinos from the Sun pass through your body every second, but virtually none of them interact with your atoms.
dailyFacts.astronomyFact.title: Astronomy Fact
dailyFacts.astronomyFact.content: A neutron star is so dense that a teaspoon of its material would weigh as much as all of humanity on Earth.
